control
Class StupidPlayer

java.lang.Object
  control.Player
      control.StupidPlayer

public class StupidPlayer
extends Player

This player concentrates on being stupid. We approach this complex task by avoiding thinking whenever possible, and acting as stupid as the game rules allow. Therefore a stupid player plays fair (shows a hand card if he can disprove a suggestion), but all other decisions are made completely on random. This implementation follows the Forrest Gump GoF design pattern.

Method Detail

play

public Suggestion play()
Description copied from class: Player
This method indicates that the players turn has begun. Therefore, the player has to announce a suggestion when this method is called. The player receives the answer from the game logic via receiveAnswer

Specified by:
play in class Player
Returns:
the suggestion the player announces
See Also:
Player.receiveAnswer(Suggestion, Card, Player, Set)

receiveSuggestion

public Card receiveSuggestion(Player questionair,
                              Suggestion suggestion)
                       throws java.lang.NullPointerException
Description copied from class: Player
When this method is called, the player is ask to disprove a suggestion. Returns null if the player is not able to disprove it, a hand card otherwise.

Specified by:
receiveSuggestion in class Player
Parameters:
questionair - player who announced the suggestion
suggestion - Suggestion to disprove
Returns:
null if cannot disprove or a disproving Card
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if an argument is null
